Q: What is the name of Ishmael’s close companion aboard the Pequod?
A:
Queequeg.

Sources: chunk_nr 929 (Moby Dick; Or, The Whale), chunk_nr 662 (Moby Dick; Or, The Whale), chunk_nr 575 (Moby Dick; Or, The Whale), chunk_nr 660 (Moby Dick; Or, The Whale).

First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had selected

“Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg.”
“Well, bring him along then.”
And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that I
had done a good morning’s work, and that the Pequod was the identical
ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round the Cape.
But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the

“Captain Peleg,” said I, “I have a friend with me who wants to ship
too—shall I bring him down to-morrow?”
“To be sure,” said Peleg. “Fetch him along, and we’ll look at him.”

Metrics.R: The score is 0.38 because the context contains directly relevant lines—'First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had selected' and 'There generally subsists between the two, a close intimacy and friendliness.'—which identify Queequeg as Ishmael’s close companion, but much of the retrieval context is irrelevant or incomplete (e.g. 'we set down who the Pequod’s harpooneers were, and to what headsman each of them belonged' and 'Yojo purposed befriending us'), diluting the useful signal and yielding a low-to-moderate relevancy score.
